awd_titl_txt: Understanding DNA-Graphene Interaction Towards Scalable Nanomanufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this project is to study fundamental interactions between graphene and self-assembling DNA towards a new manufacturing platform that can create custom-designed graphene nanostructures. DNA origami (paper-folding) structures of arbitrarily designed sizes and shapes will be hierarchically assembled and will be explored as templates/masks to define graphene nano-geometry using top-down fabrication methods. This research will investigate DNA assembly kinetics and non-covalent chemistry at the DNA-graphene interface. The effects of edge chemistry and graphene geometry on the electro-optical properties of resulting nanostructures will be assessed. Theoretical modeling and numerical computation will be performed to guide experiment.

The outcome of this research will generate new scalable nanofabrication strategies for custom-designed graphene and other electronic materials, which cannot be manufactured otherwise in a high-throughput, massively parallel fashion. The bottom-up approach will demonstrate unprecedented sub-10-nm features of arbitrary geometries, while exploiting the repeatability and scalability of conventional top-down methods. This program will integrate the research efforts with educational and outreach activities designed to advance the public understanding of biomolecular nanomanufacturing. These activities will provide opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to learn and conduct cutting-edge science and engineering in a multidisciplinary environment, and increase participation of women and underrepresented minority students.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This research aimed at establishing a strong scientific foundation of DNA-assisted nanomanufacturing for graphene and other two-dimensional (2D) materials. Synthetic self-assembled DNA nanostructures were explored as lithographic masks to define arbitrary-shaped 2D materials. The pattern transfer from DNA to 2D materials was demonstrated with unprecedented nanometer precision and repeatability. The outcome of this project includes (1) a detailed understanding of DNA interactions with 2D materials, (2) elucidation of surface chemistry and its effects on the physical properties of 2D materials, and (3) demonstration of custom-designed 2D materials and their functionalities. In addition, this research made significant advances in developing molecular symmetry-based design strategies for novel nanostructures which may not be manufactured otherwise. This project formed the basis of new nanomanufacturing technologies, enabling novel devices with new levels of system control at the nanoscale and providing scientific insights into atomically thin materials for novel opto-nanoelectronics.

 

The project activities included strong efforts integrating cutting-edge research with education and outreach. The research efforts helped create new graduate-level course materials on biomolecular nanotechnology. The topics of self-assembly, DNA origami, design principles, characterization methods, and related engineering applications were partly incorporated into existing courses. The project team implemented a hands-on experimental outreach module titled ‘Glowing Grass: Observation of Photosynthetic Units and Processes’ for K-12 students, parents, and teachers. In this module, green leaves and grass are collected, grinded, and dissolved in ethanol by the participants who can then observe chlorophylls (pigments in plants) through optical visualization. This module helps K-12 students and teachers understand natural photosynthesis through simple hands-on experiments. The feedback from the participants was extremely positive.

 

This project engaged 1 postdoctoral researcher, 13 graduate students, and 2 undergraduate students along with two faculty investigators who together published 1 book chapter and 20 journal papers. This project also provided research opportunities for 2 undergraduate (1 female and 1 minority) students. This program provided a unique multidisciplinary research environment where students of diverse backgrounds learn from each other, becoming engineers and scientists of next generation to solve the multi-faceted challenges of our society.

 


Last Modified: 11/02/2016
Modified by: Jong Hyun Choi
